channel.title: [PI] Pull Character Variables From External Class?
channel.description:
I'm working with sockets right now, and I'm having some problems.
What I currently have: Website sends an announcement to the server, and the server displays it to all the users, and sends a thank you message back to the website.
What I'm looking to achieve: I want it so that when you type in a username on the website, it requests information from the server and displays it on the site. I know how to do it all, but I don't know how to get the player variables like bankItemsN[0] and what not. I know most systems use (this) when calling to a class, but I just can't seem to get it to work. If someone can tell me how to get player information from my class it'd be [i]greatly[/i] appreciated.
Here is MyJavaServer.class which is what I use for starting the socket, processing input, and outputting an announcement. http://pastebin.com/9q8LqAtR
If it helps, sockets is started when the server loads in Server.java initialize() I added MyJavaServer.main(); to call my class and start sockets.

item.title: [PI] Pull Character Variables From External Class?
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

I’m working with sockets right now, and I’m having some problems.

What I currently have: Website sends an announcement to the server, and the server displays it to all the users, and sends a thank you message back to the website.

What I’m looking to achieve: I want it so that when you type in a username on the website, it requests information from the server and displays it on the site. I know how to do it all, but I don’t know how to get the player variables like bankItemsN[0] and what not. I know most systems use (this) when calling to a class, but I just can’t seem to get it to work. If someone can tell me how to get player information from my class it’d be greatly appreciated.

Here is MyJavaServer.class which is what I use for starting the socket, processing input, and outputting an announcement.
http://pastebin.com/9q8LqAtR

If it helps, sockets is started when the server loads in Server.java initialize() I added MyJavaServer.main(); to call my class and start sockets.
